title: 106_hr6
content: The "Marriage Tax Penalty Relief Act of 2000" eliminates the marriage penalty in standard deduction and specifies that no amendment made by the Act shall be considered a change in tax rates for tax purposes. The "Marriage Tax Penalty Relief Act of 2000" eliminates the marriage penalty in standard deduction by amending section 63(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments include adjusting the dollar amount and technical changes to subparagraphs. The "Marriage Tax Penalty Relief Act of 2000" eliminates the marriage penalty in standard deduction by amending section 63(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. The Marriage Tax Penalty Relief Act of 2000 eliminates the marriage penalty in the 15-percent tax bracket and repeals the reduction of refundable tax credits. The Marriage Tax Penalty Relief Act of 2000 eliminates the marriage penalty in the 15-percent tax bracket for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. The applicable percentage for determining taxable income amounts in the table under subsection (d) is half of the amounts determined under subsection (c) after adjustments. The applicable percentage for taxable years beginning in 2003 and thereafter is as follows: 170.3 for 2003, 173.8 for 2004, 183.5 for 2005, 184.3 for 2006, 187.9 for 2007, and 200.0 for 2008 and beyond. The text chunk discusses rounding amounts to the nearest multiple of $50, repealing the reduction of refundable tax credits, making technical amendments to the tax code, and specifying effective dates. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002, except for the repeal of the reduction of refundable tax credits which applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. Marriage penalty relief for earned income credit is provided in Section 4. Marriage penalty relief for earned income credit is provided through amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments include adjustments for joint returns and inflation. The taxable year begins with adjustments for inflation and joint returns in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2000. The House of Representatives passed the bill on February 10, 2000.
